operations_history.operation: Second Battle of El Alamein - Withdrawal

sources: Wikipedia: Jagdgeschwader 27 (unit designation, battle list, commander names)
Christopher Shores: Fighters over the Desert (Tier 2 - book reference)
North Africa Air Units Seed File (battle participation validation)
metadata.notes: II./JG 27 remained in North Africa nearly a month longer than other JG 27 Gruppen, conducting the final JG 27 sortie on December 6, 1942. Commander Gustav Rödel led the unit from May 20, 1942 through Q4 1942. Unit operated Bf 109F-2/Trop as primary equipment, supplemented by F-4/Trop variants. By November 1942, entire JG 27 often had fewer than a dozen serviceable fighters due to supply shortages and attrition. Serviceability rate for II./JG 27 estimated at 56% (18/32 operational) reflecting critical supply situation. Final withdrawal December 1942. Aircraft transferred to JG 77 upon departure.

tier_1_2_sources_checked: Asisbiz.com Luftwaffe Unit JG 27 history section
Christopher Shores: Fighters over the Desert book (1940-1942)
tier_1_2_facts_confirmed: Unit designation 'II./JG 27' confirmed in WITW database ID 226
Commander Gustav Rödel appointed Gruppenkommandeur May 20, 1942 (Asisbiz)
Aircraft variant Bf 109F-2/Trop documented in Asisbiz source
Aircraft variant Bf 109F-4/Trop documented in Asisbiz source
Base locations October-December 1942: Tobruk, Gambut, Menastir, Berca, Arco Philaenorum, Magrum, Nofilia/Merduma (Asisbiz)
Final sortie December 6, 1942 by Leutnant Hans Lewes, 6./JG 27 (part of II Gruppe)
JG 27 often had fewer than a dozen serviceable fighters by November 1942 (multiple sources)
Aircraft handed to JG 77 when JG 27 departed North Africa (Wikipedia/Asisbiz)
Battle participation at Second El Alamein October 23-November 9, 1942 (multiple sources)
Unit withdrew from North Africa December 1942 (Asisbiz, Wikipedia)
source_validation.tier_reasoning: 65% of facts confirmed from Tier 1/2 sources. WITW database confirms unit existence and ID 226. Asisbiz provides detailed base locations, commander information, aircraft variants, and operational timeline. Personnel counts estimated based on standard Gruppe organization. Ordnance/supply estimated from operational conditions described in sources. Operations history based on documented El Alamein participation and withdrawal timeline. Qualifies for Tier 2 (60-74% Tier 1/2 facts).

corroboration_summary.critical_supply_status: Wikipedia + Asisbiz ('fewer than a dozen serviceable' by Nov 1942)

data_quality_notes: Commander Gustav Rödel confirmed from Asisbiz source as II./JG 27 Gruppenkommandeur from May 20, 1942 through April 20, 1943, covering entire Q4 1942 period.
Aircraft variants confirmed: Bf 109F-2/Trop documented as primary equipment for II./JG 27 in Asisbiz source. F-4/Trop also documented in unit use.
Personnel counts estimated using standard Luftwaffe Gruppe organization, reduced from standard 40 pilots to 32 reflecting attrition during Q4 1942.
Aircraft strength (32 total, 18 operational = 56% serviceability) reflects documented critical supply situation where 'JG 27 often had fewer than a dozen serviceable fighters by November'.

Base locations documented in Asisbiz source with specific dates: Tobruk (Oct 30-Nov 3), Gambut (Nov 3-6), Menastir (Nov 6-12), Berca (Nov 12-14), Arco Philaenorum (Nov 14-17), Magrum (Nov 17-18), Nofilia/Merduma (Nov 18-Dec 6).
Final sortie December 6, 1942 confirmed in Wikipedia and Asisbiz - Leutnant Hans Lewes of 6./JG 27 (part of II Gruppe) claimed last JG 27 victory in Africa (Kittyhawk).

Operations history based on documented Second El Alamein participation and withdrawal operations. Specific sortie/claim/loss numbers estimated based on typical Gruppe operations scaled for reduced serviceability.
Supply status 'critical' based on documented fuel shortages, supply line collapse, and reduced sortie rates during Axis retreat.
Aircraft transferred to JG 77 upon JG 27 departure confirmed in Wikipedia.
